{"step_by_step_thinking": "Cherry red spot and Hollenhorst plaque are both findings associated with retinal artery occlusion. The cherry red spot refers to a red spot in the macula surrounded by a pale retina. This is seen in central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO). Hollenhorst plaques are cholesterol emboli that can be seen in the retinal arterioles. These emboli can cause occlusion of the retinal artery and are commonly seen in CRAO. Therefore, the correct answer is A. CRAO.", "answer_choice": "A"}
